subject: Re: [junit] How to add jUnit testing to an existing large JAVA project?
msgSnippet: Michael Feathers book is definitely a must! Some other reflections: Unit tests are great, one drawback is that with a large codebase you re in for a lot of
messageBody:
Michael Feathers book is definitely a must!

Some other reflections:
Unit tests are great, one drawback is that with a large codebase
you're in for a lot of work if you indent to unit test everything, and
there is also the risk of applying tests where it is easy to apply
them rather than where they should be.

I guess you will be doing some development on the code once you get it
under test ?
(if there is no purpose to writing those tests other than writing the
tests I think you should take a step back and consider the whole
thing)

A complement/alternative to unit tests could be
blackbox/system/acceptance tests, to test the system end-to-end. Those
tests will take longer to run, but on the other hand they give you
more freedom to refactor the code "under the hood" once you get it
under test, and they will verify that the functionality of the product
doesn't change over time. A risk with unit tests is that they tie down
the code, and for every change you want to make you have to change
bundles of unit tests.

I would go for an extensive system test suite, and unit tests for the
more complicated lower-level refactorings of important pieces of code.

Cheers
Daniel

> I highly recommend _Working_Effectively_with_Legacy_Code_ by Michael
> Feathers.
> (His definition of "legacy code" is simply "code without tests",
> regardless of when it
> was written, or by whom.)
>
> That book does an outstanding job of discussing how to get code under test.
> The first section, "The Mechanics of Change", describes goals and
> techniques
> of unit testing, along with general strategies for getting tests
> around code that
> wasn't designed to be tested. The second section, "Changing Software", is
> almost a set of case studies. Each chapter addresses a specific problem of
> the
> form, 'I need to ..." or "How do I ..." with clear suggestions and
> illustrations.
> The third section, " Dependency-Breaking Techniques", returns to the
> general
> level and presents a catalog of tactics for breaking code down into
> testable
> (and manageable) segments.
>
> I sincerely believe the best thing you could do (given your questions) is
> to
> read that book and start trying out the techniques it presents.
>
> Good luck!
>
> -jn-
